text: this is Simone Romero reporting from
Caracas Venezuela for the New York Times
vomit LOL um carro precioso well you see
it it's a beautiful car a Mustang this
car in Venezuela is a symbol of
Americanism and although it's a powerful
car America and its power may not be a
popular concept on the streets of
Caracas in 2010 but back in the 70s
these American cars and the power they
project ruled the road no tengo por que
me encantan five minutes of karma I have
it because i love i love the classics 30
years on many still stop the streets of
poorer neighborhoods most are heavy and
guzzle gas but with Venezuelans paying
less than 10 American cents a gallon who
cares this is a gift gasoline in
Venezuela is a gift
these cars were imported in the 1970s
when an oil boom enriched the Venezuelan
economy today they linger frozen in time
a bit like the 50s classics in Cuba
qualify lankan end this is the ford
fairlane 500 its owner is a taxi driver
and hardly moves it it's in very good
condition although it can be difficult
to keep these cars in good condition
some Venezuelans prefer them because
they're seen as a worthy investment a
hedge against high inflation me dos a
new laptop 12 years ago I paid 800
bolivares what I now as I've seen on the
internet I wouldn't sell it for less
than 42,000 bol√≠var's many are proud
possessions that have been handed down
from generations this was my father's
car it had another owner before he
restored it and gave it to me when I
graduated from high school
and for others some creative engineering
and elbow grease keep many out of the
junkyard for some young Venezuelans
these classics equal modern-day cool I
saw the car and I got excited I was
impressed with the car I said wow what a
beautiful car not knowing it was his
unless see something like that
